source.description: Insert the slide into the Countess II automated cell counter. Note the calculated live cell density. You will use this density (not the total density) to calculate the number of cells needed for seeding.

source.title: Seeding cells for BBB differentiation using single cell seeding (Day -1)

source.description:
Calculate appropriate volume of cells to add to each 6-well.
  • Typical seeding number for IMR90-4 iPSCs is between 100,000 – 120,000 cells per well.
  • Typical seeding number for CC3 and CD12 iPSCs is 150,000 cells per well

source.description: {"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":1,"offset":742,"style":"sup"}],"key":"74sso","text":"Human induced pluripotent stem cell (iPSC)-derived developmental lineages are key tools for in\u00a0vitro mechanistic interrogations, drug discovery, and disease modeling. iPSCs have previously been differentiated to endothelial cells with blood-brain barrier (BBB) properties, as defined by high transendothelial electrical resistance (TEER), low passive permeability, and active transporter functions. Typical protocols use undefined components, which impart unacceptable variability on the differentiation process. We demonstrate that replacement of serum with fully defined components, from common medium supplements to a simple mixture of insulin, transferrin, and selenium, yields BBB endothelium with TEER in the range of 2,000-8,000\u00a0\u03a9 \u00d7 cm2across multiple iPSC lines, with appropriate marker expression and active transporters. The use of a fully defined medium vastly improves the consistency of differentiation, and co-culture of BBB endothelium with iPSC-derived astrocytes produces a robust in\u00a0vitro neurovascular model. This defined differentiation scheme should broadly enable the use of human BBB endothelium for diverse applications.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"dkgh","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"fm3q1","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":1,"offset":0}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"6mdn7","text":"  ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7ire","text":"","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":[{"data":{"guid":"58AFFC70F29811E9AA86E9E695032D2F","height":154,"id":49590,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"677jp","text":"Schematic of E6 method for BBB differentiation","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":[]},"mime":"image\/png","original_name":"image.png","placeholder":"https:\/\/s3.amazonaws.com\/protocols-files\/public\/1618c1a37f153002e3885d7ebd72cd0a4e653895bbeb80a8934c28142d836cb2\/bspy7vcw.png","source":"https:\/\/s3.amazonaws.com\/protocols-files\/public\/1618c1a37f153002e3885d7ebd72cd0a4e653895bbeb80a8934c28142d836cb2\/bspy7vcw.png","type":1,"width":624},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"image"}]}
